docs.lead_paragraph: IN 14 years as a public health nurse for the Dutchess County Health Department in New York State, Evelyn Kaufmann spent many days giving talks at campgrounds and schools around the Hudson Valley about avoiding the tiny ticks that carry the bacteria causing Lyme disease. But several years ago she was stricken by Lyme herself. Despite her expertise, she never noticed the bite of the tick or recognized the subtle symptoms that emerged over the next six months: sporadic headaches, fevers, aches and occasional memory lapses. Finally, she was tested and cured with antibiotics.

headline.main: First Shot Is Fired In the War On Lyme Disease

docs.abstract: First commercial vaccine against Lyme disease infection is available; vaccine, called Lymerix, was developed and tested by SmithKline Beecham of Philadelphia over last eight years and approved by FDA in December; but FDA approval comes with long list of caveats, and Federal officials and Lyme experts stress that vaccine will mainly benefit people who live in areas where ticks are most numerous and who have jobs or life styles that fequently take them into tick habitat; by far the biggest potential market for vaccines is seen in suburbs and shoreline communities around southern New England and New York metro region, where millions of people frequent forests and beach areas that are thick with ticks; Federal health officials limit license for Lymerix to people between ages of 15 and 70, with trials still under way to test its effectiveness and safety in children; even after prescribed three shots spaced over 13 months, it confers protection less than 80 percent of time, making it less effective than, say, polio vaccine, but more effective than typical flu shot; charts show states with most reported cases, and highest incidence of cases; photos (L)
docs.snippet: IN 14 years as a public health nurse for the Dutchess County Health Department in New York State, Evelyn Kaufmann spent many days giving talks at campgrounds and schools around the Hudson Valley about avoiding the tiny ticks that carry the bacteria...

headline.main: First Shot Is Fired In Lyme Disease War

docs.abstract: Doctors on Long Island are beginning to use SmithKline Beecham's vaccine called Lumerix, recently approved by Food and Drug Administration, in fight against Lyme Disease; biggest potential market for vaccine is seen in suburbs and shoreline communities around southern New England and New York metropolitan area; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE'S probably no single reason why hundreds of people are streaming into the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford each week to view the collection of 300-year-old paintings by Pieter de Hooch (pronounced dah HOKE). Some are no doubt enchanted with the artist's idealized visions of 17th-century life in the Netherlands. Others may go to admire his delicate treatment of light and texture. Still others may know that this is the first time de Hooch, commonly sampled in survey books, has gotten a show of his own. Peter C. Sutton enjoys it for all those reasons. An art historian and author of two books on de Hooch, Mr. Sutton finds something ''preternatural'' in the way the Old Master gave life and depth to his creations.

headline.main: Home-Grown Style at a Venerable Museum

docs.abstract: Interview with Peter Sutton, director of Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, Conn; he comments on his ambition of revitalizing museum, building membership and attendance; since Sutton's arrival in 1996, Atheneum has embarked on ambitious program of home-grown exhibitions, 13 this year alone; he comments on current popular exhibition of paintings by Pieter de Hooch; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the Rainbow Room closed a month ago, New Yorkers lost a glittering and much loved nightspot, and 250 workers lost their union jobs. Now that new owners are planning to reopen the restaurant and club -- famed for its romantic ambiance and 65th-floor Manhattan views -- the former workers are demanding their jobs back. On Friday, more than a dozen of them picketed outside Rockefeller Center, accusing the owners, the Cipriani family, of illegally refusing to consider hiring any former workers in favor of a new, nonunion, largely part-time staff.

headline.main: Former Workers Demand Jobs at Rainbow Room

docs.abstract: Former workers at Rainbow Room accuse Cipriani family, new owners of recently closed Manhattan nightspot, of refusing to consider hiring any former workers, who belong to Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union; former workers picket premises and urge boycott (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE state's Department of Social Services is preparing to start spending about $1 million to publicize the eligibility of up to 90,000 Connecticut young people up to age 19 for ''free or affordable'' health-care coverage. State and Federal legislation, some old, some recent, came together to make possible wider promotion of the program, called Healthcare for Uninsured Kids and Youth, or Husky, which became effective July 1. If its promise is fulfilled, the program could help achieve the goal of having a form of universal health care insurance in force in Connecticut, at least for children and adolescents.

headline.main: Spreading the Word About Health Care for Children

docs.abstract: Connecticut's Social Services Dept is preparing to start spending about $1 million to publicize eligibility of up to 90,000 Connecticut young people up to age 19 for 'free or affordable' health-care coverage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton is proposing a major expansion of Medicare to cover prescription drugs, a change long sought by older Americans, and a Federal advisory commission may soon endorse the idea. But drug companies are gearing up to fight any plan for the Government to provide prescription drugs as a basic benefit in the traditional Medicare program. They fear that it would lead to Federal regulation of drug prices, which is anathema to the industry.

headline.main: Clinton's Plan to Have Medicare Cover Drugs Means a Big Debate Ahead in Congress

docs.abstract: President Clinton is proposing major expansion of Medicare to cover prescription drugs, change long sought by older Americans; drug companies, however, are gearing up to fight any plan for Government to provide prescription drugs as basic benefit in traditional Medicare program; they fear that it will lead to Federal regulation of drug prices and that private insurers would follow Government's example and demand deep discounts as are made to Medicare (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As a nurse turned computer systems manager, Laureen West is one of a crowd of consultants able to describe how year-2000 computer malfunctions could interrupt the distribution of medicines. But as a brain tumor patient who needs daily doses of synthetic-thyroid and other drugs to stay alive, the 43-year-old Mrs. West has no rivals when it comes to convincing listeners that it matters. Mrs. West's obvious lack of ease in talking publicly about a condition she long kept private only adds to the wallop when she speaks, whether to church groups here in her hometown, to seminars for health care officials or, as in October, to a Senate subcommittee as an expert witness on Y2K, as the year-2000 problem is known.

headline.main: The Millennium Glitch, and Life and Death

docs.abstract: Laureen West, brain tumor patient, has become expert witness on year 2000 computer problem and its relevance to nation's drug supply; West has joined others in drawing attention to their demand that health officials give public more information on how it plans to handle distribution of drugs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BABY boomers seem to be focused on three economic issues: their homes, their retirements and their children's college educations. But a fourth potential drain on their resources tends to sneak up on them: their parents. The parents of the baby boom generation are getting older, and may not be prepared for the financial strains of declining health. Last month, President Clinton proposed a $1,000-a-year tax credit for the chronically ill and, in some cases, for relatives who care for them, but that would hardly dent most such health care bills.
docs.abstract: James Schembari column says baby boomers are reaching the point where they may encounter unexpected financial obligations if their aging parents become ill or disabled and require long-term care; says that they should begin delicately sounding their parents out on these matters and that parents reluctant to share their concerns with their children should be advised to consult a financial planner or lawyer specializing in elder law (M)
docs.snippet: BABY boomers seem to be focused on three economic issues: their homes, their retirements and their children's college educations. But a fourth potential drain on their resources tends to sneak up on them: their parents.    The parents of the baby...

docs.lead_paragraph: You have a 50-50 chance of getting a salary increase of 4 percent or more this year, according to Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a compensation company based in Bethesda, Md. In a survey of 397 companies in five industry sectors, Watson Wyatt found that the median salary increase budgeted for 1999 was 4 percent.

headline.main: Compensation Growing From Top to Bottom

docs.abstract: Watson Wyatt Worldwide reports that median salary increase budgeted for 1999 by the 397 companies it surveyed is 4 percent; says differences in merit pay increases among industries are insignificant (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 14 years as a public health nurse for the Dutchess County Health Department, Evelyn Kaufmann spent untold hours giving talks at campgrounds and schools about avoiding the tiny ticks that carry the bacteria causing Lyme disease. But several years ago she was stricken by Lyme herself. Despite her expertise, she never noticed the bite of the tick or recognized the subtle symptoms that emerged over the next six months: sporadic headaches, fevers, aches, and occasional memory lapses. Finally, she was tested and cured with antibiotics.

headline.main: The First Shot Is Fired In the Lyme Disease War

docs.abstract: Arrival of Lymerix, SmithKlein Beecham's vaccine against Lyme disease, does not mean that people in tick-invested areas can let down their guard; the protection it offers against Lyme is less than 80 percent, and it offers none against other diseases borned by same tick; research is under way that could lead to ultimate weapon, a vaccine that causes a tick to abandon its effort to bite after a tentative nibble or causes the body to react with such a pronounced itching feeling that the tick bite is impossible to miss; photos; graphs (L)
